posts.name: Carmine
posts.cooked: Hey, everyone, for the 2025 - 2026 season, I am going to be team 2022 's electrical lead. I was wondering if anyone had some specific tips or tricks regarding teaching, wiring, etc. Anything yall have to give would be much appreicated. Thanks!

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked:
These seem like low hanging fruit, but these are simple things teams miss a lot and its usually immediately apparent in their electrical if they arent paying attention to it.

Cut wires slightly longer than you think they need to be.  You dont want wires to be pulled super tightly especially if youre using zip ties or other cable management tools to route your electrical lines.  You’ll also want some slack in the event things need to change or if you end up needing to re do connectors or strip wires again for any reason.  im not saying to leave a loop or bundle, but a little extra is nice.

Think logically about routing wires, you dont want a gigantic bundle of random cables that will be hard to sort through when troubleshooting. Be deliberate ie. bundle the motors for one swere module together in its own line, keep an individual subsystem grouped, keep CAN organized with its location or subsystem, etc.

basically a little forethought and organization goes a long way to making electrical clean and serviceable in a pinch.  there are obviously things you could do outside of this that are more advanced but these are usually the first things i teach students interested in doing the electrical work.

posts.name: Chris Cross
posts.cooked:
Do you have an electrical mentor or at the very least, a mentor who has some knowledge of FRC electrical/electronic components?  If so, work closely with them.

Tug test everything! Practice wire stripping and crimping. Try not to bundle power cables with communication cables. Look here on CD for wiring diagrams that someone did a few months ago.  Very helpful. Download/view all the documentation for all electronic components that you will use on your robot.  We started a binder this year to keep it all handy. Think about and organize your wire runs before running them. Read the game manual for details about minimum wire gauges for components and where to connect them. Those should get you started!

Here is the thread for the updated control system diagrams.  Very useful! 2025 Unofficial FRC Control System Diagrams - Technical / Electrical - Chief Delphi

posts.name: Alex
posts.cooked: To add onto what others said, being able to navigate REV Hardware Client and Phoenix Tuner is very useful to diagnose errors. Also, know what status LEDs mean, especially how to differentiate between “no CAN ” and “good CAN ” states.

posts.name: Maaz_Hawa
posts.cooked: On our robot this past year, our motors were very spread out, and trying to find a specific set of power wires through a wire highway was not pretty. We zip-tied most of our power wire sets together because we wanted to stay organized and have all of our wires in one general area. This backfired on us when we needed to trace a specific wire set back to the PDH , and some wire sets got extremely hard to follow through a wire highway. Since you seem like you are talking from experience, how do you bundle the wires for each motor/motor set individually without losing organization? Also, do you have a picture of your robot’s wiring that I could take inspiration from?

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
Do a tug-test on each and every individual wire immediately after making each and every connection (screw terminal, push button terminal, lever nut, solder joint, etc.). Tug-test each wire in a pair separately because if one of a pair is secure and the second is not, the pair may appear to be secure.

Read the documentation for all the control system components to find the strip-lengths for all the connectors used.

Work out the routing of wires (bundles) by taking screenshots of the 3D CAD from various viewpoints then drawing in the wires (bundles) using the drawing tool. Use different colors for the high-current wires, low-current wires, and signal wires.

When securing the wire bundles, do not tighten the zipties too much. It should be possible for the wires to shift a little when pulled. It becomes impossible to trace wires when the zipties are too tight.

Treat the control system as one of the subsystems in the robot. Reserve space for it in the early stages of the detailed design of the robot and firmly enforce it. Ensure that there is adequate access to the battery, main breaker, radio, and other control system parts for construction, repair and troubleshooting. Someone from the electrical group should be frequently reviewing the CAD design of the robot to ensure that access is not blocked and that the placement of the electrical components makes sense.

The larger the wires, the more priority should be put into reducing their length. Thus, the highest priority should be put on reducing the length of the wires from the battery SB-50 connector to the main breaker to the PDH / PDP and back to the SB-50.

Design the control system parts to be installed on sub-panels that can be built up in parallel with the assembly work of the robot chassis. It may even be possible to do some basic pre-tests on the control system before the sub-panels are installed in the robot.

Use other forms of training, such as mechanical, to select people who demonstrate good attention to detail and good workmanship to be trained to do the electrical construction. It will be much easier to get a good, reliable control system. With previous teams, I would personally check the control system before the first competition. Typically, there would be 1/4 to 1/3 of the connections would have to be redone. Using this method of choosing members of the electrical team, I have not inspected the control system for the last 3 seasons and we have not experienced any workmanship related failures in the control system.

posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
I wrote this a number of years ago. Some of the control system components have changed since then, but most of the suggestions still apply. (Ignore the title, it was a thing at the time)

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Liam
posts.cooked:
My advice is labeling on both ends. We spend a lot of time (specifically on our comp bot) labeling all of our power wires to the pdh as we almost always bundle them together. It’s worth having 1 person sitting ready with a label maker equipped with the heat shrink labels to organize the wiring.

CAN is its own beast, and not something we label unless it gets very lost in the weeds.

posts.name: Andrew Todd
posts.cooked: Red to red, black to black!

posts.name: Mert Ata BABER
posts.cooked: This, in my experience FRC components don’t smell good when red is connected to black.

posts.name: Gavin
posts.cooked:
In general a goal should be to have every connector restrained on the robot, zip tie squares, or I prefer some of these , are helpful for that. Hot glue is good and you should use it to help strain relief connectors, etc, but make sure not to overdo it and bring 99% iso alcohol to remove it if need be ( these tiny bottles are great for that ) If you are using powerpoles make sure anyone who crimps them is very experienced in how to do it well, since its not as easy to tell if a bad crimp is causing issues visually compared to something like wagos (easier visual inspection is why we switched to wagos, but I don’t really think they are better, go with what you know). On that thought always strip enough when using wagos, its marked on them.

For can: solder or molex sl, Molex sl has been working great for us if you want a hotswappable connector like that.

If you use spark maxes for the love of god don’t use the double crimped rev jst connectors. Just crimp your own or order thriftybot ones.

posts.name: philso
posts.cooked:
I lent my team my Brother D410 label maker because it is possible to make a spreadsheet of the labels then print each with a click, or two, of the mouse. The label maker is connected to a laptop loaded with free software from Brother (not all models are capable of doing this). This makes it easier when making many different labels. We were able to format the labels to appear similar to the ones made by the professional label makers at my workplace. They are wrapped around the wire (pairs).

posts.name: Saber_8871
posts.cooked:
Okay, so admittedly its post season and through a combination of disassembly for transport and other factors it isnt as clean as we would normally like but here are some images of our wire packaging and tracing

20250501_143307 1920×1440 307 KB

20250501_143307 1920×1440 307 KB

20250501_143307 1920×1440 307 KB

The red and blue boxes represent both front end swerve drive lines, the green represents one side of our pivoting controls for out pivoting elevator.  Normally this would be labeled in robot, but this was done in such a rush we didnt have time to place that in this season (wiring was completed like 3 days prior to our first regional.  We also run a stacked electronics board which can definitely introduce some headache, running cable in a logical manner keeps it from being too bad for maintenance. It also protects cables from external faults while also making the electrical look cleaner from the outside.

20250501_143315 1920×1440 296 KB

20250501_143315 1920×1440 296 KB

20250501_143315 1920×1440 296 KB

Another example of wire packaging from the module side.  The wire in the foreground is one of the previously mentioned pivot motor runs but is packaged separately from the module for easy troubleshooting.

Honestly, this isnt the cleanest set of cable runs for us, but its definitely better than a birds nest and allows us to quickly troubleshoot electrical issues on the fly. its just unfortunate i cant lift the stack to show the underside wire runs without removing the entire elevator assembly.

EDIT: bonus as to what our electrical lookes like 3 seasons ago before i started overseeing it more closely as the lead mentor.

posts.name: Daniel Herring
posts.cooked: CAN WAGOs + Hard Impacts = dead robots on field

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: CAD subordinate and Drive team/Pit Crew member, also Enby

posts.name: Calvin Hou
posts.cooked: I had no issues wiring can through Wago 221 inlines last year both on the rio bus and the canivore FD bus, I think the key part to doing them is just using ferrules. Our robot definitely had some pretty hard impacts and had no electrical issues throughout the season.

posts.name: Daniel Herring
posts.cooked:
Maybe for an experienced wiring team, but for a team like ours in 23 where you have an inexperienced group doing wiring, and you don’t have everything 100% sure it’s a really unnecessary risk to take when it only takes 5 minutes to solder and heat shrink those wires. I don’t think our team has ever had a soldered wire break.

I say this, but it should be noted that WAGOs are great when you are figuring out how to route the wires early on so that you can easily change what’s going on.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: CAD subordinate and Drive team/Pit Crew member, also Enby

posts.name: Calvin Hou
posts.cooked: … our wiring in 24 was literally all done by me, and it was the first robot I had ever fully wired. Soldering is arguably a whole lot easier to mess up, especially with heatshrink. If there is any failure under that, you will have a super fun time finding it. Its near literally impossible to messup ferrules + wagos, given you strip enough wire and use a decent ferrule crimper.

posts.name: Daniel Herring
posts.cooked: fair enough

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: CAD subordinate and Drive team/Pit Crew member, also Enby

posts.name: George Horsey
posts.cooked:
The following list is what our team does. I’ve seen a few duplicate items from previous messages.

Plan the Route Collaborate with the design team to plan where wires will be routed. While we don’t typically place wires in CAD, we measure the model and compare the available space to real-world wire bundles to visualize routing paths during the design phase.

Plan the Route Collaborate with the design team to plan where wires will be routed. While we don’t typically place wires in CAD, we measure the model and compare the available space to real-world wire bundles to visualize routing paths during the design phase.

Group Similar Wires Group power wires separately from data/signal wires. This organization reduces strain, especially on CAN wiring—critical for SparkMax JST CAN connectors.

Group Similar Wires Group power wires separately from data/signal wires. This organization reduces strain, especially on CAN wiring—critical for SparkMax JST CAN connectors.

Inspect and Test Crimps Visually inspect each crimp and perform a pull test. We supervise the first few crimps for any connector, and if they meet spec, we keep one as a reference. If a crimp is poor, we provide direct feedback for correction. Every connection gets a few sharp tugs to ensure it’s properly seated and clipped in. For PowerPole connectors, we add a zip tie once they’re fully landed to keep them secure.

Inspect and Test Crimps Visually inspect each crimp and perform a pull test. We supervise the first few crimps for any connector, and if they meet spec, we keep one as a reference. If a crimp is poor, we provide direct feedback for correction. Every connection gets a few sharp tugs to ensure it’s properly seated and clipped in. For PowerPole connectors, we add a zip tie once they’re fully landed to keep them secure.

Label and Pair Wires Cable wrap-style labels are ideal. Even a simple tape flag with a number helps identify wire pairs—saving time when using a multimeter. Zip ties or plastic cable wrap (where space allows) along each wire pair’s route keep things neat and organized.

Label and Pair Wires Cable wrap-style labels are ideal. Even a simple tape flag with a number helps identify wire pairs—saving time when using a multimeter. Zip ties or plastic cable wrap (where space allows) along each wire pair’s route keep things neat and organized.

Use Grommets When Passing Through Metal Anytime wires pass through the robot frame or metal parts, use grommets to prevent abrasion. DigiKey Part Number: 3720-2053-ND

Use Grommets When Passing Through Metal Anytime wires pass through the robot frame or metal parts, use grommets to prevent abrasion. DigiKey Part Number: 3720-2053-ND

Avoid Ferrules for Weidmuller Terminals Ferrules can interfere with Weidmuller connections (like on the VRM , PCM , or Vivid Hosting radio), as the colored boots sometimes press the release button. In these cases, we lightly tin the ends of the wire instead.

Avoid Ferrules for Weidmuller Terminals Ferrules can interfere with Weidmuller connections (like on the VRM , PCM , or Vivid Hosting radio), as the colored boots sometimes press the release button. In these cases, we lightly tin the ends of the wire instead.

Minimize Soldering Avoid soldering where possible. We allow it only for PCB connections and when tinning wire ends for Weidmuller terminals. Soldered wires become brittle at the solder-to-copper transition—often under insulation—making breaks harder to diagnose. When tinning, we keep solder only at the tip to hold strands together without letting it wick under the insulation.

Minimize Soldering Avoid soldering where possible. We allow it only for PCB connections and when tinning wire ends for Weidmuller terminals. Soldered wires become brittle at the solder-to-copper transition—often under insulation—making breaks harder to diagnose. When tinning, we keep solder only at the tip to hold strands together without letting it wick under the insulation.

Use WAGO Connectors Appropriately WAGO connectors are more reliable with larger gauge wires. Smaller wires—even with ferrules—can slip out if the lever is bumped, so take care in those cases.

Use WAGO Connectors Appropriately WAGO connectors are more reliable with larger gauge wires. Smaller wires—even with ferrules—can slip out if the lever is bumped, so take care in those cases.

Use Fir Tree Clips for Cable Management Fir tree clips are a great solution for clean cable routing. DigiKey Part Number: 1436-1962-ND

Use Fir Tree Clips for Cable Management Fir tree clips are a great solution for clean cable routing. DigiKey Part Number: 1436-1962-ND

Limit Igus Chain Length Igus chains work best in short lengths unless held under tension. Longer sections tend to whip around and can snap at the joints during robot motion.

Limit Igus Chain Length Igus chains work best in short lengths unless held under tension. Longer sections tend to whip around and can snap at the joints during robot motion.

Color Code Power Wires Use red for positive and black (or another consistent color) for negative throughout the robot to quickly identify polarity and avoid mistakes.

Color Code Power Wires Use red for positive and black (or another consistent color) for negative throughout the robot to quickly identify polarity and avoid mistakes.

Double Check Device Voltages Ensure the correct voltage before connecting devices to power. FRC has a mix of mostly 5v and 12v devices.

Double Check Device Voltages Ensure the correct voltage before connecting devices to power. FRC has a mix of mostly 5v and 12v devices.

Use Consistent CAN Layout Keep your CAN bus daisy-chained in a logical order (e.g., front-to-back or drivetrain-to-subsystems), and clearly mark the start and end points with 120-ohm terminators where required.

Use Consistent CAN Layout Keep your CAN bus daisy-chained in a logical order (e.g., front-to-back or drivetrain-to-subsystems), and clearly mark the start and end points with 120-ohm terminators where required.

Leave Service Loops Leave small service loops near connections to allow for movement, strain relief, and easy replacement—particularly in tight or high-vibration areas.

Leave Service Loops Leave small service loops near connections to allow for movement, strain relief, and easy replacement—particularly in tight or high-vibration areas.

Secure Battery Cables Separately Battery leads should be firmly secured and isolated from signal wiring to avoid disconnection and EMI noise.

Secure Battery Cables Separately Battery leads should be firmly secured and isolated from signal wiring to avoid disconnection and EMI noise.

Use a Multimeter Regularly During Builds Verify continuity, voltage, and polarity at multiple points during the wiring process—not just at the end.

Use a Multimeter Regularly During Builds Verify continuity, voltage, and polarity at multiple points during the wiring process—not just at the end.

Document Wiring Layouts Take photos or create diagrams of wire routing and connections for easier troubleshooting and repair during competitions.

Document Wiring Layouts Take photos or create diagrams of wire routing and connections for easier troubleshooting and repair during competitions.

posts.name: Kade Rabe
posts.cooked: teach them general skills obv like crimping, what connectors to use, how to wire and diagnose CAN , stuff like that. but smth that helped the people i have taught is letting them wire a whole robot, then reviewing what could have been improved, in terms of reliability, cleanliness.
